lexUnit.name: shopping.n

document.description: Berlitz What to Do in Hong Kong
document.name: WhatToHongKong

document.description: Berlitz Where to Go in Hong Kong
document.name: WhereToHongKong

lexUnit.definition: COD: the purchasing of goods from shops.

sentence.text: Shopping never ends - there 's always another inviting spot just down the street .
Next to the Jardine building is Exchange Square , a complex with a large shopping mall ; just behind it is the General Post Office with a philatelic center on the ground floor .
At the upper terminus there is a four - level shopping center , the Peak Galleria , and the Peak Tower , which resembles an airport control tower and has shops , entertainment , and restaurants .
It is more interesting for its architecture than for its shopping ; it 's situated in a four - story Edwardian building built in 1906 .
Take the Mid - Levels Escalator to Hollywood road , known for its antiques and curio shopping .
A prosperous tourist district , it is full of shopping centers and department stores , along with a number of good restaurants .
All-inclusive packages and large resort hotels offer restaurants , sporting activities , entertainment , wide - screen sports channels in the bars , shopping , and a guaranteed suntan .
Across Victoria Harbor , connected by ferry and the MTR rail line , is the Kowloon peninsula with its hotels , nightlife , and almost non-stop shopping .
Shenzhen is a premier shopping center , and much cheaper than Hong Kong .
Just across the border is the huge Lo Wu City shopping mall , to which you can walk ; other shopping malls are nearby .
While it 's no longer the bargain shopping destination it once was , there are still some good buys to be had .
You 'll find that prices are about the same in Hong Kong Central and Kowloon , and somewhat cheaper in Causeway Bay , which caters to local shopping .
Stores do not open until 10 am or later , but shopping goes on into the evening , up to 9:30 pm .
